awd_titl_txt: New forms of silicon with enhanced optoelectronic properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Unlike metals that freely conduct electricity, semiconductors require energy input to promote electrons into conducting states. The minimum input energy, known as the band gap, is either direct or indirect depending on the specific crystalline structure. Silicon, which is essential for the vast majority of modern electronics and solar energy devices, possesses an indirect band gap meaning that light absorption and emission are feeble processes. In contrast, direct band gap materials are effective absorbers and emitters of light. Recent theoretical calculations indicate energetic feasibility for numerous forms of crystalline silicon with direct band gaps, but experimental synthesis pathways are not available. This research team aims to create entirely new forms of crystalline silicon that possess direct band gaps in order to improve optoelectronic properties that impact a range of technologies including solid-state detectors, optical communication and energy conversion devices. Research is focused on novel synthetic pathways that combine high- and low-pressure experiments in order to achieve access to kinetically-stabilized states. More generally, the development of novel synthesis methodologies broadly affects metastable materials beyond silicon. This research project occurs within an educational environment that emphasizes the career development of students and postdoctoral scholars.  

Technical description: This project utilizes a new approach for metastable materials synthesis through a combined high-pressure / ambient-pressure hybrid method. Numerous metastable silicon allotropes with enhanced optoelectronic properties are predicted to exist within 30 kJ/mol of the ground state, but effective synthesis pathways are lacking. By initiating ambient-pressure chemical synthesis from precursors formed under high-pressure conditions, entirely new synthesis pathways are possible due to the high-energy state of the recovered precursor that is metastable at ambient conditions. This effort explores the depth of realizable materials in silicon and probes the relationships between metastable allotropes and optoelectronic properties in order to create entirely new metastable crystalline allotropes that possess direct or quasidirect band gaps. The research contributes to the longstanding limitations associated with the indirect band gap of the cubic diamond structure. Experiments are conducted at high-pressure conditions in order to optimize single-crystalline growth and at low-pressure conditions to optimize precursor transformations. The intrinsic optical and electronic transport properties of novel silicon allotropes are established experimentally, and the library of potential high-pressure precursor materials is supported by calculations including density functional theory-based structure searching. The overall goal of the project is to produce and characterize new silicon phases exhibiting improved optical activity.

por.por_cntn:
Silicon is one of the most important semiconductors for electronic and optoelectronic devices, however the indirect nature of the band gap places limitations on applications, particularly those associated with the absorption and emission of light. Using novel, high-pressure processing methods, this project contributed to the development of entirely new forms of silicon and silicon-based compounds with enhanced optoelectronic properties within a research environment that promoted the career development of students and postdoctoral scholars.

High-pressure synthesis represents a unique approach to access novel materials that are challenging or impossible to obtain by conventional approaches. Furthermore, materials recovered from high-pressure conditions may serve as unconventional precursors to create entirely new materials. Following this high-pressure precursor approach, a new orthorhombic allotrope of silicon, Si24, was produced by extracting sodium ions from metastable Na4Si24. Si24 has a quasidirect band gap near 1.3 eV and potential for improved optoelectronic properties compared with conventional diamond-cubic silicon.

This research project resulted in the development of synthetic methods to produce single-crystalline Na4Si24 and demonstrated the removal of sodium to produce the first single-crystalline Si24 with precise structural determination. Optimization of the sodium extraction process resulted in the production of Si24 crystals with at least 99.999% purity, and the availability of high-purity Si24 crystals allowed for the determination of near-intrinsic optical and electronic properties including the optical absorption coefficient, electron donor impurity levels, reduced electron mass, and electron relaxation time. Thermodynamic properties including the bulk modulus and thermal expansivity were also established.

This research project also resulted in the first bulk synthesis of another silicon allotrope, 4H-Si, which is a hexagonal structure comprised of ABCB stacking along the crystallographic c-axis. By utilizing Si24 as a precursor material, different pressure-temperature pathways were established to produce 4H-Si. 4H-Si was determined to have a structural relationship with Si24, which yields a low-energy transformation pathway compared with the diamond-cubic silicon ground state. Highly oriented, microcrystalline bulk 4H-Si was produced, enabling structural determination and the characterization of physical properties. Similar to diamond-cubic Si, 4H-Si was determined to possess an indirect band gap near 1.2 eV. 4H-Si represents a promising candidate to produce tunable direct-gap alloys with germanium, and its elastic properties are relevant to future microelectronic devices.

In addition to pure allotropes, this research also investigated several silicon-based compounds including mixtures with germanium and boron. Using high-pressure synthetic approaches, new ternary Na-Si-Ge and Na-B-Si compounds were discovered, and their structures and physical properties were evaluated. Such compounds offer the possibility to produce intrinsic semiconducting materials without the need for post-synthetic manipulation and provide a wide range of tunable materials properties based on bulk composition.

The development and discovery of new silicon allotropes and compounds in this project may contribute to significant technological developments including efficient solar cells, novel solid-state detectors and devices that integrate optical and electronic function. The novel synthesis and processing methods developed in this work may also be transferrable to other classes of materials. Finally, this project contributed to the career development and training of students and postdoctoral scholars.
